sql.statement: CREATE TABLE glossary (_id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY NOT NULL , entry_title TEXT, entry_body TEXT, pic_1 TEXT, pic_2 TEXT);

INSERT INTO "glossary" VALUES(1,'Apothecia','Apothecia (s. apothecium) are the reproductive structures of the mycobiont (fungal partner), containing the spores produced by the fungus. Generally, they are cup or disk shaped.','apothecia_web','NULL');

INSERT INTO "glossary" VALUES(2,'Asci','Asci (s. ascus) are the spore-containing structures of a fungus found in the hymenium. In lichens, the mycobiont produces spores through meiosis, which are housed in an ascus. A single ascus represents a single meiotic event followed by a mitotic event. Therefore each spore within an ascus results from the same mother cell after it undergoes meiosis, making ascospores useful in the study of fungal genetics.','asci','NULL');

INSERT INTO "glossary" VALUES(3,'Cephalodia','Cephalodia (s. cephalodium) are structures on lichens containing two photobionts (both an algae and a cyanobacteria). They house the cyanobacteria and usually appear as black lumps on the surface of a lichen.','cephalodia_web','cephalodium');
INSERT INTO "glossary" VALUES(4,'Cilia','Cilia, when in reference to lichens, refers to marginal hair-like structures of some lichens.','cilia','NULL');

INSERT INTO "glossary" VALUES(5,'Cortex','The cortex is the upper and/or lower layer of a lichen composed entirely of gelatinized fungal cells. It offers protection to the rest of the lichen.','cortex1','NULL');

INSERT INTO "glossary" VALUES(6,'Crustose','A crustose lichen is one that grows so tightly appressed to its substrate that they generally cannot be separated without destroying the lichen. Also called the “crust lichens.”','NULL','NULL');

INSERT INTO "glossary" VALUES(7,'Cyphellae','Cyphellae are small round pits on the lower surface of some lichens that open to the medulla, but lined with specialized cells. In North America, they are unique to the genus Sticta.','cyphellae_web1','cyphellum');
INSERT INTO "glossary" VALUES(8,'Foliose','A lichen with a foliose growth habit has a distinct upper and lower dorsiventral surfaces, appearing “leaf-like”.','NULL','NULL');
INSERT INTO "glossary" VALUES(9,'Fruticose','A lichen with a foliose growth habit has a distinct upper and lower dorsiventral surfaces, appearing “leaf-like”.','NULL','NULL');
INSERT INTO "glossary" VALUES(10,'Hymenium','The hymenium as the upper tissue of an apothecium that contains the asci and paraphyses.','apothecium_copy','NULL');
INSERT INTO "glossary" VALUES(11,'Hypothecium','The hypothecium is the layer of fungus just below the hymenium.','apothecium_copy','NULL');

INSERT INTO "glossary" VALUES(12,'Isidia','Isidia are asexual reproductive structures of the lichen, characterized by being covered with a cortex. Often, they look like small fingers projecting from the surface of the lichen, but may take many other shapes, as well.','isidia_psax2_scale_web','NULL');

INSERT INTO "glossary" VALUES(13,'Lobules','Lobules (syn. phyllidia) are asexual reproductive structures on lichens. They form from budding-off of the main thallus, and are characterized by being stratified in the same way as the main thallus, appearing as miniature versions of the main thallus.','pelt_elis_lobules1','NULL');
INSERT INTO "glossary" VALUES(14,'Medulla','The medulla is the middle or lower layer of a stratified lichen that contains the mycobiont.','torb_stratification_falsecolor1','NULL');
INSERT INTO "glossary" VALUES(15,'Mycobiont','The mycobiont is the fungal parter in a lichen. Being a fungus, the mycobiont is heterotrophic.','NULL','NULL');
INSERT INTO "glossary" VALUES(16,'Ostiole','An ostiole is the opening of a perithecium or pycnidium that allows spores to exit the lichen thallus.','pycnidia_webtorb','NULL');
INSERT INTO "glossary" VALUES(17,'Paraphyses','Paraphyses are sterile fungal filaments found in an apothecium. ','asci','NULL');

INSERT INTO "glossary" VALUES(18,'Perithecia','Perithecia (s. perithecium) are spore-containing structures of a lichen. They are usually immersed in the thallus surface, and appear as black dots on the surface of the lichen. Perithecia differ from other spore-containing structures by being almost entirely enclosed except for a small opening through which the spores exit–the ostiole.','perithecia_web','NULL');

INSERT INTO "glossary" VALUES(19,'Photobiont','The term photobiont refers to the photosynthesizing (autotrophic) partner in a lichen. It may be a green algae or a cyanobacteria, or both.','cortex1','NULL');

INSERT INTO "glossary" VALUES(20,'Pruina (Pruinose)','Pruina refers to a powdery covering that may be present on some lichens. It consists of chemical deposits on the surface of the lichen. A pruinose lichen typically appears dull and sometimes whitish rather than shiny.','pruina_peltigera_web','NULL');

INSERT INTO "glossary" VALUES(21,'Pseudocyphellae','Pseudocyphellae are pores in the thallus surface that open to the medulla, and can appear in various spots on a lichen. ','pseudocyphellum','NULL');

INSERT INTO "glossary" VALUES(22,'Pycnidia','Pycnidia (s. pycnidium) are asexual reproductive structures of some lichens. They appear as black dots on the thallus or sometimes as small bumps on the thallus surface. They are open on top and are lined with spores from the mycobiont.','pycnidia_web','NULL');

INSERT INTO "glossary" VALUES(23,'Soralia','Soralia (s. soralium) are the structures on a lichen thallus that yield soredia. They appear as an erosion of the cortex covered in granular masses.','soralia_web','soralium');

INSERT INTO "glossary" VALUES(24,'Soredia','Soredia (s. soredium) are asexual reproductive structures containing both the photobiont and the mycobiont, and having no cortex. Often, they appear as a powdery or granular covering on the lichen thallus.','p_anomala_scale_web','NULL');

INSERT INTO "glossary" VALUES(25,'Spore','A spore cell (or cells) released by the mycobiont in apothecia, capable of growing into a new fungus. Spores are a form of asexual reproduction of the fungus.','ascus','spore_bse');

INSERT INTO "glossary" VALUES(26,'Stratified','The term stratified, when used in reference to a lichen, refers to a lichen that exhibits partitioning of algal and fungal partners within the thallus (contrast with non-stratified).','t_orb_web1','NULL');

INSERT INTO "glossary" VALUES(27,'Squamulose','A squamulose lichen is one that has a growth habit of producing squamules, or small, overlapping parts of the thallus, as in basal thallus of many species of Cladonia.','NULL','NULL');
INSERT INTO "glossary" VALUES(28,'Umbilicate','An umbilicate lichen grows attached to the substrate only at a single point, the umbilicus. Perhaps the best example is Umbilicaria.','NULL','NULL');

CREATE TABLE lichen_index (_id PRIMARY KEY NOT NULL , genus TEXT, species TEXT, substrate TEXT, thallus_type TEXT, habitat TEXT, apothecia TEXT, soredia TEXT, isidia TEXT, pycnidia TEXT, cilia TEXT, rhizines TEXT, pseudocyphellae TEXT, notes TEXT, forest_type INTEGER, full_binomial TEXT, pic_1 TEXT, pic_2 TEXT, pic_3 TEXT, pic_4 TEXT, pic_5 TEXT);

INSERT INTO "lichen_index" VALUES('15','Evernia','prunastri','Hardwood and conifer branches, trunks.','Fruticose.','Widespread.','Rare.','Yes, from sparse to abundant.','Sparse to absent.','N/A','N/A','N/A','N/A','Differentiated from similar looking Ramalina species by having a green upper surface and white underneath.','---','Evernia prunastri','ev_prun1','ev_prun111','ev_prun118','ev_prun2','ev_prun5');

INSERT INTO "lichen_index" VALUES('22','Hypotrachyna','sinuosa','Hardwood and conifer branches, trunks.','foliose','something','Uncommon.','Yes, on lobe tips.','No.','No.','No.','Yes, branching dichotomously.','No.','Common, distinguished by terminal soralia and abundant rhizines.','---','Hypotrachyna sinuosa','hypot_sin1','hypot_sin2','hypot_sin227','hypot_sin4','hypot_sin5');

INSERT INTO "lichen_index" VALUES('25','Lichenomphalia','umbellifera','Most often on rotting wood and stumps.','Mushroom with decurrent gills; growing from small, dark green squamules.','Widespread.','N/A','N/A','N/A','N/A','N/A','N/A','N/A','One of the few lichenized Basidiomycetes. Common. ','---','Lichenomphalia umbellifera','lic_umb1','lic_umb2','lic_umb3','lic_umb4','NULL');

INSERT INTO "lichen_index" VALUES('43','Ramalina','delicerata','Hardwood and conifer branches.','Fruticose','Widespread.','Yes, abundant, light green. ','No.','No.','No.','No.','No.','No.','The abundant apothecia are the most obvious character of this species. Color is often faded, appearing yellow/white.','---','Ramalina delicerata','ram_del1','ram_del2','ram_del3','NULL','NULL');

INSERT INTO "lichen_index" VALUES('46','Usnea','cornuta','Common on both hardwoods and conifers.','fruticose','Widespread, common.','None','Yes','Yes','N/A','N/A','N/A','N/A','Recognized by fibrils and side branches that taper as they connect to main branches. Central cord thin compared to overall branch diameter; medulla also thin, wispy.','---','Usnea cornuta','usn_corn1','usn_corn2','usn_corn3','usn_corn362','usn_corn364');
